members.docComment:
/**
 * Error handling plugin. Namespace: `error/`.
 *
 * Makes failures explicit in the AST via try/catch, fail, attempt, guard, and settle combinators.
 */
members.name: error
errorInterpreter

members.docComment:
/**
 * Structured error handling operations added to the DSL context.
 *
 * Provides try/catch, fail, orElse, attempt, guard, and settle combinators for explicit, AST-level error handling.
 */
members.name: ErrorMethods

members.docComment:
/**
 * Attempt an expression and return an Either-style result. The result has `.ok` and `.err` properties.
 * ```
 * const result = $.attempt(
 *   $.sql`select * from users where id = ${id}`
 * )
 * // result.ok  — Expr<T | null>  (null if failed)
 * // result.err — Expr<Error | null> (null if succeeded)
 *
 * return $.cond($.eq(result.err, null))
 *   .t(transform(result.ok))
 *   .f({ error: result.err })
 * ```
 *
 */

excerptTokens.text:
<{
        ok: T | null;
        err: any | null;
    }>

members.name: attempt

members.docComment:
/**
 * Explicitly fail with an error value. This is `throw` for the DSL.
 * ```
 * $.cond($.eq(user, null))
 *   .t($.fail({ code: 404, message: 'not found' }))
 *   .f(user)
 * ```
 *
 */
members.name: fail

members.docComment:
/**
 * Validate a condition, failing if it's false. Like an assertion in the program.
 * ```
 * $.guard($.gt(user.age, 18), { code: 403, message: 'must be 18+' })
 * ```
 *
 * If the condition is true, continues. If false, fails with the given error. Useful in `$.begin()` chains:
 * ```
 * return $.begin(
 *   $.guard($.gt(balance, amount), 'insufficient funds'),
 *   $.sql`update accounts set balance = balance - ${amount}`,
 *   { success: true }
 * )
 * ```
 *
 */
members.name: guard

members.docComment:
/**
 * Unwrap an attempted expression, providing a default on failure. Sugar for `$.try(expr).catch(() => default)`.
 * ```
 * const user = $.orElse(
 *   $.sql`select * from users where id = ${id}`,
 *   { name: 'anonymous', id: 0 }
 * )
 * ```
 *
 */
members.name: orElse

members.docComment:
/**
 * Collect results from multiple expressions, accumulating both successes and failures instead of failing fast.
 * ```
 * const results = $.settle(
 *   $.sql`select * from service_a`,
 *   $.sql`select * from service_b`,
 *   $.sql`select * from service_c`
 * )
 * // results.fulfilled — array of successful values
 * // results.rejected  — array of errors
 * ```
 *
 * This is `Promise.allSettled` for the DSL.
 */
members.name: settle

members.docComment:
/**
 * Attempt an expression that might fail. Returns a builder with `.catch()` and `.finally()`.
 * ```
 * $.try($.sql`select * from users where id = ${id}`)
 *   .catch(err => ({ error: err.message, data: null }))
 * ```
 *
 * Without `.catch()`, an unhandled failure propagates up (equivalent to re-throwing). The `.catch()` provides the recovery branch.
 */
members.name: try
eval_

members.docComment:
/**
 * Expr<T> is the phantom-typed wrapper around every value in the DSL. At runtime it's a Proxy. At the type level it carries T so your IDE gives you completions and errors.
 *
 * The brand symbol lets plugins detect "is this already a Mvfm value or a raw JS primitive?"
 */
members.name: Expr

members.docComment:
/**
 * Concurrency plugin. Namespace: `fiber/`.
 *
 * Provides `par` for parallel execution, `seq` for sequential execution, `race` for first-to-complete, `timeout`, and `retry` combinators.
 */
members.name: fiber
fiberInterpreter

members.docComment:
/**
 * Concurrency primitives added to the DSL context.
 *
 * Provides par, seq, race, timeout, and retry combinators that describe concurrency structure in the AST for the interpreter to execute.
 */
members.name: FiberMethods

members.docComment:
/**
 * Run expressions in parallel, return all results. This is the safe `Promise.all` -- with mandatory concurrency limit.
 * ```
 * // Run 3 things concurrently (default concurrency = Infinity for tuple form)
 * const [users, posts, stats] = $.par(
 *   $.sql`select * from users`,
 *   $.sql`select * from posts`,
 *   $.fetch`https://api.example.com/stats`
 * )
 *
 * // Map over a collection with bounded concurrency
 * const details = $.par(userIds, { concurrency: 5 }, (id) =>
 *   $.sql`select * from details where user_id = ${id}`
 * )
 * ```
 *
 */
members.name: par

members.docComment:
/**
 * Run expressions concurrently, return the first to complete. Other branches are conceptually cancelled.
 *
 * const data = $.race( $.fetch`https://primary.api.com/data`, $.fetch`https://fallback.api.com/data` )
 */
members.name: race

members.docComment:
/**
 * Retry an expression up to N times with optional delay.
 * ```
 * const data = $.retry(
 *   $.fetch`https://flaky.api.com/data`,
 *   { attempts: 3, delay: 1000 }
 * )
 * ```
 *
 */
members.name: retry

members.docComment:
/**
 * Run expressions sequentially, return last result. This is `$.begin()` with fiber awareness -- each step is guaranteed to complete before the next starts.
 *
 * Alias for `$.begin()` but makes the intent clearer in a concurrent context.
 * ```
 * $.seq(
 *   $.sql`insert into users ...`,
 *   $.sql`insert into accounts ...`,
 *   $.sql`select * from users where ...`  // returned
 * )
 * ```
 *
 */
members.name: seq

members.docComment:
/**
 * Timeout an expression. If it doesn't complete within the given milliseconds, the fallback is used.
 * ```
 * const data = $.timeout(
 *   $.fetch`https://slow.api.com/data`,
 *   5000,
 *   { error: 'timeout' }  // fallback value
 * )
 * ```
 *
 */
members.name: timeout

/**
 * Walk an AST subtree and inject a runtime value into matching `core/lambda_param` nodes.
 *
 * This is the standard mechanism for evaluating lambda expressions at runtime: clone the lambda body, inject the argument value into the param nodes, then recurse through the interpreter to evaluate the body.
 *
 * @param node - AST subtree to walk (typically a cloned lambda body)
 *
 * @param name - The param name to match against `core/lambda_param` nodes
 *
 * @param value - The runtime value to inject
 */
members.name: injectLambdaParam
